english_translation: Narrated by Ismail ibn Ibrahim who said: Laith ibn Abi Sulaim narrated to us from Mujahid from Abdullah ibn Umar that he was asked about the rock which was in Jerusalem. He said to him: Some people say... (mentioning their claim), but Allah is far above what they say in exaltation and greatness. So Abdullah ibn Umar trembled in fear and compassion when they described Him with bounds and movement. Abdullah ibn Umar said: 'Indeed Allah is greater and more magnificent to be described with the descriptions of the created things. This is the speech of the Jews, enemies of Allah. Rather they say: Al-Rahman rose over the Throne, meaning His command and power are over His creation.' Laith said: Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah said: 'May Allah fight the people of Syria, how disbelieving they are, or he said how misguided they are, saying that Allah placed His foot on the rock of Jerusalem...' and al-Hasan said: 'His mention, praise and glory rose over His creation, and Allah the Blessed and Most High is not described with movement from one place to another.' It was said Hushayim was asked about that and he said: 'Our scholars used to say: He overpowered the Throne.' And al-Hasan said regarding His saying 'Then He rose to the heaven while it was smoke': meaning His command and power and gentleness became supreme over His creation, and Allah is not described with the descriptions of the created, nor does description fall upon Him as it falls upon creation. And Abdullah ibn Masud, Aisha, Abdullah ibn Umar, Ibn al-Hanafiyyah, and Urwah ibn al-Zubayr used to reject what the people of Syria said about the rock and forbid from it and were strict about it.

english_translation: Regarding His saying: 'And (O Moses!) thou wast reared under Mine eye' - Ibn Abbas said: 'Meaning you were nurtured by My command.' Al-Hasan said: 'Nurtured by My knowledge.' And Mujahid and al-Dahhak said: 'By My knowledge.' And similarly His saying: 'The Ark is moving under Our eyes' - meaning by Our knowledge and protection, for Noah's Ark was protected from the flood, and Moses was protected from Pharaoh and his people until Allah made him a Messenger who spoke with Him. That is the special favor which Allah granted to Moses. And if His saying 'And (O Moses!) thou wast reared under Mine eye' meant what the ignorant people claim - that He created him before his eyes - then there would be no virtue for Moses because Pharaoh would see him just as Moses sees Pharaoh. But rather He meant you were raised under My protection, care, and guarding until you conveyed what Allah willed from His messages and command.

english_translation: Regarding His saying: 'As-Samad' - Ubay ibn Ka'b said: As-Samad did not beget and was not begotten, and there is no one like unto Him. He has no equal and no like, and there is nothing like unto Him. And Abdullah ibn Masud was asked about As-Samad and said: The One turned to in needs. And al-Hasan said: As-Samad is the One to whom the servants turn in their needs and supplications and requests. And Said ibn Jubayr said: The One turned to in needs. And Said said: Whoever made a monotheistic statement claiming that He has no hollow interior, He is too great for perceptions to fall upon His description or intellects to comprehend the extent of His greatness, but rather As-Samad is the Master. And Ikrimah said: As-Samad is the Omnipotent above His servants.

Said said in the hadith of Asim ibn Kulaib: If I knew who said this anthropomorphism I would have done to him such-and-such. And Ali ibn Asim said: It is the truth. english_translation: Narrated: Abdullah ibn Masud passed by an elder teaching about the Torah. When he saw Ibn Masud he became silent. Ibn Masud said: What has your friend been telling you? They said: He mentioned that when Allah created the heavens and the earth, He ascended to heaven from Jerusalem and placed His foot on the rock of Jerusalem. Ibn Masud gasped in disgust, then said: O Allah, there is no disbelief after faith, repeating this several times. Then he said: 'They wish that you disbelieved as they disbelieved so you might be equal.' I think this is none other than Satan manifesting in his form. Then he said: Why did you not reject him and say as the righteous servant Abraham said: 'I love not those that set.' He means the setting, the transient. So beware, the Jews upon your religion. And he said: A time will come upon people when they pray, fast, and perform pilgrimage, yet if you shot an arrow among them you would not hit except a disbeliever or hypocrite, because polytheism is more hidden than the creeping of ants on a black stone in the dark night. And that is from their denial of their Lord in their hearts where they described Him with bounds and movement.

potential_issues.impact: This is a chapter reference to a Quranic verse, not an actual hadith

english_translation: Regarding what you asked about the saying of the disciples to Jesus: 'Can your Lord send down a table for us from heaven', and you mentioned that this indicates Allah is in the sky and they did not ask Him from the Throne. But if that indicated He is in the sky without the earth, then the statement of the Children of Israel to Moses would indicate that Allah is in the earth without the sky, because bringing forth from the earth is like sending down from the sky. Allah the Exalted is the Determiner of all things as He wills, some He determines from the sky and some from the earth. He is the Creator and Manager of that. The meaning of the disciples' request from the sky is because that is more evident for creation and greater for the answer and clearer for the sign, because that is something the creation cannot claim, neither sorcerer nor soothsayer. Rather, Allah by His mercy and favor manages affairs from where He wills without moving or changing.

english_translation: Narrated by Abu Sufyan from Azwar: A man from the Muslims from Oman, from the best of the elders I have encountered: Women from Oman sought permission to visit Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. She allowed them and they entered and greeted her. Then she said: Who are you? They said: From the people of Oman. She said: I have heard my beloved, upon him be peace, say: Many of those who drink from my Pond will be from the people of Oman. Abu Sufyan said: It reached me that women from Syria entered upon Aisha and she asked them: Where are you from? They said: From Syria. So she said to them: Perhaps you are among those who use the bathhouses. The women were silent. Abu Sufyan said: It reached me that a wife of Muawiyah ibn Abi Sufyan entered upon Aisha. And Aisha placed a leather cushion under her and turned toward a part of the house, then brought a bowl of bread with broth and poured milk on it and said: Eat. Muawiyah's wife smiled and said: O Mother, we return to something softer than this, meaning fine food. Then Aisha sighed deeply and said: The Prophet of Allah died without being satisfied with bread soaked in broth. Then she said: The Prophet of Allah died without being satisfied with barley bread.
